BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Afternoon: Gradual increase in avalanche danger. New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The soft wind slabs are mostly small and in some cases prone to triggering.
The weather will be mild.
Midday and afternoon: Over a wide area over a wide area 5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1800 m. As a consequence of a strong wind from westerly directions, sometimes large wind slabs will form above the tree line. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on very steep north, east and south facing slopes. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
Slab avalanches are possible in the evening, but they can reach medium size in some cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
5 to 10 cm of snow fell on Friday above approximately 2000 m.
The covering of new snow is soft.
The upper section of the snowpack is largely stable and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a crust. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on steep, little used shady slopes. Towards its base, the snowpack is largely stable.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Sunday: The weather will be mild. Evening and night: Down to intermediate altitudes snow will fall.

The soft wind slabs are mostly small and in some cases prone to triggering.

Midday and afternoon: Over a wide area over a wide area 5 to 15 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1800 m. As a consequence of a strong wind from westerly directions, sometimes large wind slabs will form above the tree line. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on very steep north, east and south facing slopes. BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Afternoon: Gradual increase in avalanche danger. New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The soft wind slabs are mostly small and in some cases prone to triggering.
The weather will be mild.
Midday and afternoon: Over a wide area over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1800 m. As a consequence of a strong wind from westerly directions, sometimes large wind slabs will form above the tree line. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on very steep north, east and south facing slopes. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
Slab avalanches are possible in the evening, in particular medium-sized ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
5 to 10 cm of snow fell on Friday above approximately 2000 m.
The covering of new snow is soft.
The upper section of the snowpack is largely stable and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a crust. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on steep, little used shady slopes. Towards its base, the snowpack is well consolidated.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Sunday: The weather will be mild. Evening and night: Down to intermediate altitudes snow will fall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Afternoon: Gradual increase in avalanche danger. New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The soft wind slabs are mostly small and in some cases prone to triggering.
The weather will be mild.
Midday and afternoon: Over a wide area over a wide area 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall above approximately 1800 m. As a consequence of a strong wind from westerly directions, sometimes large wind slabs will form above the tree line. These can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases in particular on very steep north, east and south facing slopes. In particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
Slab avalanches are possible in the evening, in particular medium-sized ones.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
5 to 10 cm of snow fell on Friday above approximately 2000 m.
The covering of new snow is soft.
The upper section of the snowpack is largely stable and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a crust. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on steep, little used shady slopes. Towards its base, the snowpack is well consolidated.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Sunday: The weather will be mild. Evening and night: Down to intermediate altitudes snow will fall.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering above approximately 2400 m. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In isolated cases avalanches are medium-sized.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. The old snowpack is largely stable. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust below approximately 2600 m. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind.

From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Over a wide area over a wide area 5 to 10 cm of snow will fall above approximately 400 m. The new snow will be deposited on a favourable old snowpack in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers in all aspects. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in north to northeast to northwest facing aspects and on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of low temperatures and solar radiation the snowpack consolidated. The snowpack remains unfavourable in particular on very steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering above approximately 2400 m. Avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In isolated cases avalanches are medium-sized.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. The old snowpack is largely stable. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust below approximately 2600 m. In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust. The snowpack will be subject to considerable local variations. Snow depths vary greatly above the tree line, depending on the infuence of the wind.

From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.

The fresh and older wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering in particular on northwest to north to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines.

On steep grassy slopes more small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. This applies in particular in the regions with a lot of snow.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust below approximately 2600 m. As a consequence of new snow and wind the wind slabs will increase in size moderately towards the evening.
Towards its base, the snowpack is moist, in particular below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force wind from northwesterly directions, further wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind and new snow above approximately 2000 m, especially along the border with France. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: 5 to 10 cm of snow, and up to 15 cm in some localities, will fall from the afternoon. As a consequence of new snow and a moderate to strong wind from westerly directions, sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs will form. In some places avalanches can also be released in near-surface layers of the snowpack and reach medium size in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. The fresh and older wind slabs are to be avoided. The avalanche prone locations are to be found on steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. Above approximately 2500 m these avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of low temperatures, snowfall and the moderate to strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed during the last few days. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2500 m. Below approximately 2000 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions, depending on the infuence of the wind.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The weather will be mild. Slight increase in danger of dry and moist avalanches as the moisture increases. Above approximately 1600 m snow will fall from the afternoon.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The more recent wind slabs represent the main danger. Some new snow at low altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence above approximately 2200 m.
Weak layers in the old snowpack necessitate defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in the high Alpine regions. Wind slabs are easy to recognise. Avalanche prone weak layers exist in the old snowpack in particular on shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs and weakly bonded old snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Weak layers in the old snowpack can be released especially by large additional loads in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. This applies on very steep slopes above approximately 2400 m. Avalanches can reach large size in isolated cases.

The fresh and older wind slabs are in some cases prone to triggering in particular on northwest to north to southeast facing aspects above approximately 2400 m. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines.

On steep grassy slopes more small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. This applies in particular in the regions with a lot of snow.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Faceted weak layers exist in the centre of the snowpack in particular above approximately 2400 m.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust below approximately 2600 m. As a consequence of new snow and wind the wind slabs will increase in size moderately towards the evening.
Towards its base, the snowpack is moist, in particular below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will persist. As a consequence of new snow and a strong to storm force wind from northwesterly directions, further wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind and new snow above approximately 1200 m, especially along the border with Switzerland. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: 5 cm of snow fell yesterday. 15 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, will fall from the afternoon. In the last few days sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in all aspects. The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant above approximately 2400 m. In some places avalanches can also penetrate down to the ground and reach medium size in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation. The avalanche prone locations are to be found on steep slopes and adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The fresh and older wind slabs are to be avoided.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of low temperatures, snowfall and the moderate to strong wind, fresh snow drift accumulations formed during the last few days. The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2400 m. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions, depending on the infuence of the wind. Below the tree line only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will increase a little during the day.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular in the southwest 10 to 20 cm of snow, and up to 30 cm in some localities, fell yesterday. In addition sometimes avalanche prone wind slabs formed in high Alpine regions. The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released easily or naturally especially on north to east to south facing aspects above approximately 2400 m, caution is to be exercised adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
In some places new snow is lying on an icy crust. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones less snow than usual is lying. Below approximately 2100 m from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying. Snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. The snowpack is largely stable and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong melt-freeze crust. Towards its base, the snowpack is moist.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Slight increase in danger of moist snow slides as a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche prone locations are very rare. From a snow sport perspective, insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: 5 cm of snow, and up to 10 cm in some localities, fell yesterday. In some places new snow is lying on an icy crust. Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In all altitude zones hardly any snow is lying. The snowpack is largely stable and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a strong crust.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: From a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Avalanches can in isolated cases be released, in particular by large loads. This applies in particular on very steep shady slopes at elevated altitudes, and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example. Wind slabs are clearly recognisable to the trained eye. Mostly avalanches are small.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Thus far only a little snow is lying. Wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls and at elevated altitudes. They are mostly small.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs above approximately 1800 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche conditions are mostly favourable. Isolated small avalanches are possible in isolated cases. The avalanche prone locations are to be found especially in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will become generally stable. Adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls mostly small wind slabs formed.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The more recent wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, but mostly only by large additional loads,. Some new snow at low altitude.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The wind slabs are to be found in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in the high Alpine regions. Wind slabs are easy to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The wind slabs can be released by large loads at their margins in particular.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The snowpack will be generally stable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow is lying on top of a quite favourable old snowpack in all aspects above approximately 400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack is fairly homogeneous and has a loosely bonded surface.
